FR.question: It's admittedly rather difficult for me to think of an argument against UHC just because I'm such a large proponent. In the US context, the most common contra argument I hear is that the US is "too large" to implement such measures. So I guess I'll go with that.
Costs are too much to cover universally and would be applied unfairly to different income levels with the rich supporting the poor.
free market fundamentalism, I guess
They may not want to pay the additional taxes. They may believe the federal government should not have this role in the marketplace. They may think that health outcomes will deteriorate.

The most prominent argument for universal healthcare utilized empathy for poor, low income, or disabled individuals. While Medicare, Medicare, CHIP, and other governmental programs exist for individuals in a tight stop, financially or otherwise, many low and middle class families do not have health insurance. As a result, universal health care would cover these people and that would help them and make others feel good.
Universal Health Care is considered to be a humane allocation of health care resources in that it is not dependent on the patient’s ability to pay

People who don’t have to pay for health care or get reduced salary in order to get benefits will consume more health care than they need. If you suddenly let everyone have coverage, there would not be enough doctors to manage everyone and the currently insured would have to wait longer for appointments.

The government cannot or will not do a good job of implementing healthcare.  Government run healthcare will be wasteful, inefficient, and poorly managed.  The current system needs improvement, but UHC is not the way to do it.
It removes the link of employment and healthcare. Employment and healthcare should not be linked as you should be the one who makes decisions about your health, not the employer

People are not entitled to health care. They should be independent members of society or depend upon support from the family and direct community in times of need. It is not the responsibility of others to support them. Too much social welfare is a burden on the government debt and/or tax system when we need to be more fiscally responsible and be paying down government debt/keeping government small and taxes low. Giving the government too much power/income makes citizens vulnerable if the government becomes corrupt.

Healthcare is a service that should be dealt with like any other service, in the manner with which it's most cost effective for the taxpayer, which is privately and not publicly. UHC is also impossible to implement in the United States on a national level as the US a much larger country than other UHC countries that have a more educated and smaller population.
It is too expensive. It would require either a significant tax increase or significant deficits. Either way, this cost would outweigh the benefit.
It will cause rationing of health care. There will be lines at the doctor and you will wait months for care. Also, the government is terrible at everything and will make healthcare worse.

The government has no place in determining the quality of care I receive. The free market is the best way to distribute services for everybody. I already pay too much in taxes and UHC would raise them even higher.
Everybody regardless of social status would be able to recive healthcare. People born with rare disease by chance would not be punished. No or at least few medical bankruptcies.
We do not have the money to pay for it
Health care costs in the United States are too high; the purchasing power of the Federal Government should be used to being them down.

Universal healthcare (UHC) forces the government to decide what kinds of diseases to cover and not cover. This can lead to politically disfavored groups being blocked access to care, such as transgender people. It also could lead to corruption in the government decisions of what treatments to cover.
Government-mandated healthcare forces out competition and results in poor quality care without available alternatives.
It carries a high cost burden to all taxpayers.  Compensation rates for providers must be carefully maintained to ensure availability of services.
Health care is a right. Universal health care is the only way to ensure that everyone can get the health care that they need.

UHC is unrealistic because for-profit capital markets lead to the best price outcomes when providers and users can compete on price. Furthermore people should take personal responsiblity for healthcare costs and I don't want my taxes to be raised in order to pay for an unemployed persons healthcare. Enacting UHC would be a drain on the economy or cause employers to hire less if they we increased taxes to pay for it.
It would discourage people from taking personal responsibility to maintain their own health.

They could claim that it is not the role of the government to administer healthcare and a smaller government that does less is more ideal. They could also claim that healthcare administered by the private market is more cost effective and more choice in healthcare drives affordability through competition. Additionally they could claim that medical innovation depends on the market forces of the private market.
Coverage. UHC provides a safety net where all individuals have insurance.

That they do not see the utility in paying taxes into a system that pays for someone else's care. There is also a high chance (>65%) that they will speak to "government inefficiency" as a reason to oppose a UHC system being administered by the federal government.

The cost of universal healthcare is daunting and there is, as of yet, no clear plan to pay for such an endeavor. With ~350 million people needing care, this is a crucial part of the plan which is almost never discussed in detail. This is the most important missing piece, in my opinion.
Universal healthcare enslaves medical professionals because it forces them to provide a service to people.

The necessary tax increases to pay for universal health care in the US would be a significantly drain on the US economy and would further exacerbate the problems we already experience with our rapidly rising federal deficits. While other western democracies are able to do this, that is primarily because health care is generally cheaper there and they do not have the added burden of maintaining the world's largest and most advanced military which effectively subsidizes their security.
People will be compelled to contribute to a government medical fund that they would otherwise not choose for themselves, if they had the option.
There has to be an incentive for people to work. The government giving things out makes people lazy and slows the economy.

There isn’t enough revenue to pay for a universal healthcare program, or there would need to be cuts elsewhere. Perhaps some people like the choice or appearance of choice in choosing healthcare services.
People do not deserve to die simply for being poor. Therefore, the government should pay for everyone's healthcare.

One possible argument he may use, is the one that sounds like "Universal health care means worse quality and longer wait times" and while it is wrong, it is popular.  This comes from a sense that everything in America is the best, which I call nativism.

Universal healthcare will cost too much and bankrupt the country. The country cannot afford to spend the estimated 32.6 billion dollars over 10 years that UHC will cost. Taxes will have to be raised for everyone.
Cost of living and taxes are already a burden. Adding universal health care would only increase that burden and make it more difficult for families to move forward in the world.
Free use, and no competition will lead to increased wait times, rationing care, and less innovative research
UHC would be far too expensive and would nearly double the size of the federal government. It would also put tens of thousands of people out of work due to the size of the private insurance market.
Expense.  /  /  / Universal healthcare is too expensive to implement.

They would say that it's too expensive, in that it's going to raise taxes.  They are having trouble making ends meet already, and it's going to lessen their take-home pay even more which will make their life more difficult.

Universal Health Care would lead to increased taxes and reduce consumer choice. Governments rarely efficiently administer services better than private companies. A better solution would be to remove current government limitations and oversight of the healthcare markets to reduce price and increase access among private businesses providing health care/health insurance.

If healthcare was universal nobody would have to declare bankruptcy due to medical bills. In a system with universal healthcare nobody would go without medical care. In a universal healthcare system everybody would be entitled to the same treatment regardless of their wealth.

Government control of the market will remove price signals from the system of health provision. The lack of price signals will lead to inefficient resource allocation and shortages. The ultimate effect will be worse health outcomes than a health system organized around free-market principles.

Competition in a market place benefits all participants in that market by providing incentive for innovation and reduced prices. Universal health care removes a significant amount of competition by relying on a single payer. Further, one could argue that the move to a single payer system moves agency away from individuals - some economists hold that money is most efficiently allocated by an individual earning and utilizing it on themselves, and least efficiently by a third party who spends it on another third party. In other words, it's very easy to squander money when you didn't earn it and you aren't benefiting from its allocation.
Access to healthcare is a fundamental human right that everyone should have. X countries in Europe implemented this and had success.

it necessarily requires that money be redistributed from those who are well off to those who are less well off. The mechanism/entity that manages and provides for universal healthcare -- i.e., the government -- suffers from being inefficient and ineffective at other tasks, so adding an additional complex task is likely to achieve similar results. Finally, the cost is potentially too high.
It would take care of people who have no insurance likely through no fault of their own.  People would no longer have to take jobs they hate just for the healthcare coverage.

Health care is a right, and no one should have to go without medical care because they can't afford it, or go bankrupt just because they got sick. Therefore, the government has an obligation to make decent health care available to everyone regardless of ability to pay.
The scalability of costs could bring down the average visit price

It is unfair that people are struck blindly by life and get put in a position that the cost of Healthcare can completely ruin them. The cost is outrageous, and having people use emergency rooms as their only option is shameful.  Universal health care would mean everyone gets equal treatment and therefore is a moral imperative.

The current Healthcare system in the United States is poorly implemented and designed to allow extreme abuses by insurance companies and Healthcare providers towards patients in the form of massive and unjustified price hikes. Many Americans are unable to afford even basic Healthcare, and this often leads to them not seeking treatment until it becomes severe, at which point the overall cost becomes much worse than yearly preventive tests. Under a universal Healthcare system, these people would be able to get preventive care and treatment for their conditions, which would improve their quality of life. This is ultimately one of the main reasons for a government to exist, and therefore universal Healthcare is a necessary program to implement.

Due to the great wealth in the US, access to medical care should not be blocked due to financial conditions. We should tax the upper brackets to subsidize the poor. By cutting out the middle men we will make insurance more affordable.

Health care is a human right and as a result the state has a responsibility to ensure it's available to all. All other civilized nations have some form of universal health care; the US should catch up.
Universal healthcare would ensure that everyone has healthcare.
People should be responsible for their own fate. The government should be limited and not involve itself in the private insurance business.
Would not like the government to be in control of health care, thinks it is over reach. Doesn't like 'socialism'.

The cost of healthcare keeps going up and has already become too expensive for most people. It would cost less overall if we had a universal healthcare system. Other countries in the world already have some sort of state-run healthcare systems and the United States should follow their lead.

Everyone deserves a few basic things like having access to clean water, healthcare, and a decent paying job. Nobody should have to suffer or worry about their health whilst greedy corporations and their shareholders horde wealth. These systems have already been proven to work in European countries so there's no reason we cannot as well with all the wealth of this nation.

That it's cheaper than our current system because spending is set by Congress.  Most profit incentives are removed and insurance is kind of moot.  It does provide for everyone and automatically solves the emergency care problem.

The costs of health care in the United States are astronomical.  Moreover, our health outcomes are not necessarily better-achieved under the current system; whereas, in some European countries, universal health care provides better quality care at lower costs.  The United States should adopt universal health care not only because it's the moral thing to do, but also because it will ensure that everyone has access to health care.
That it's expensive to taxpayers. It's an entitlement program and constitutes a transfer of wealth from wealthier Americans to poorer Americans.

One of the key arguments against universal healthcare is that the free market provides a better distribution of scarce resources.  In this case that means access to healthcare.  With limited resources such as doctors, it is important that they see patients who are able to pay for their services.  If the system were to be taken off of the free market, then the availability of doctors might decrease due to less compensation, further restricting the availability of healthcare to members of society who can afford to pay for it.

that their tax dollars shouldn't pay for the poor health choices others make and that each person should pay their own way. I imagine their position might also be to let the free market determine health prices.
One argument I have commonly seen used in favor of universal health care is that healthcare is a human right. As such, it must be guaranteed by the government and financed by taxation.

Universal health care will be too expensive to implement and will generate too great a burden on the taxpayer. People should be responsible for their own health and finances, and it shouldn't fall to others to bear the cost of their decisions.
He might say that healthcare prices are too high under our current system and that universal healthcare will lower prices. He's wrong, of course.
The implementation of UHC could save hundreds of lives.  Also, the right to health care is a human right.

Universal health care would allow for all members of society to have equal access to health care services. Treating health problems as they arrive can alleviate government costs in the future, such as treatment for more severe medical conditions. This can allow for money to be spent elsewhere, such as education or national defense.
Greed and selfishness or not looking out for ones self-interest. That's all their is. Or perhaps some sort of misguided pride.

Is healthcare a right or a privilege? Can we as a country really afford healthcare for all? Do we even have enough general doctors let alone specialists to accommodate everyone. How do reimbursements work for doctors?

Everyone should be responsible for their own healthcare. They shouldn't be required to pay taxes to support poor people. They feel the capitalist system has worked for America and there's no reason it shouldn't work in healthcare

Everyone is given the same treatment regardless of economic standing. This is important as healthy individuals are good for the collective society in that they are better able to produce for that society.
It it much to expensive. The cost associated with providing all people healthcare is so high as to make it impractical.

"It works in other countries!" - It doesn't, without major faults. / "It'll save lives!" - It won't, and puts your life in the hands of your government. / "It'll be cheaper!" - It's not, everyone pays for it.
Universal health care would lower the quality of care that healthcare providers could give.
It costs a lot of money.  Taxes would have to go up in some form, possibly income tax.

People don't want assume responsibility for other people's health decisions. Something along the lines of "I try hard to be fit and healthy, so I shouldn't be required to subsidize those that choose to eat twinkies all day"

People would not get to choose their provider. Their taxes may be raised and they might not need as much healthcare as someone else. Why should you pay as much for healthcare when someone else gets sick or injured more often?

In other countries with UHC there are issues with getting a new PCP and pediatricians. Also elective surgeries are sometimes difficult to schedule as doctors prioritize other surgeries that are necessary. These wait lists can be annoying to people.
It shouldn't be my family's responsibility to take care of someone else's family. Life is hard, and if you don't have the resources to take care of yourself, that's on you.
Taxes are too high, and too many people take advantage of government assistance as it is.
A limited number of facilities will cause long waits. People who could before see docs whenever would need to schedule far out. Competition for a limited resource.
The cost of UHC, and where the money to pay for it will come from
People should support themselves rather than rely on others to provide for their needs. Healthy communities are built from strong, independent individuals.
A flood of the market meaning long wait times and subpar services.
They might believe that since they are young and healthy, they do not want their tax money to go to sick or unhealthy individuals.

The cost. Who will pay for it, how will it be implemented (the infrastructure to support it, the staff needed to assist); the country is running a massive budget deficit and this will surely only add to it.
They don't want to pay for other people's health care. They already think they pay enough taxes, and having more is unthinkable.

It is too expensive, it will cost taxpayers too much and burden people. It is unfair for people to get something from the government without having worked for it. It's socialist. It's inefficient. It hasn't worked in other countries and is going bankrupt
That people or states should own the responsibility for providing their own healthcare and that we don't want everyone basically on health welfare with the government having to take care of them
He probably thinks it's the individuals responsibility to pay for health care and should "get a job"

Doctors will make less money. The healthcare industry in general, including pharmaceuticals, will not generate as much money, which will destroy jobs. Wait time to see physician will increase. Fewer attendees to medical school. To get the best healthcare in a timely manner you will still have to pay for it, so increase in taxes and an increase in your expenses since we all know companies won't give it to you, and most likely won't give raises (in general) to compensate for their gain. So the working American people will basically subsidize the less fortunate twice.
It makes no sense paying for other people’s insurance. I want to spend my money on my life, not have to pay for some poor prostitute that needs another abortion.
People are afraid of government control of health care decisions.  They are afraid of having their choices limited by bureaucrats.
Cost. Its unfair to make people pay for others health issues.
That taxes will increase to pay for universal healthcare which will place an undue burden on hardworking people.
It isn't fair for hard working people to have to pay for other people's illness. More people will not work or be less productive if they don't have to work to support their medical costs.
They might like the healthcare that we have now, because they only consider what works for themselves and not others
Not enough money. We shouldn’t give handouts. Not the govt problem.

One argument I imagine he might have against universal healthcare is how to pay for it. Specifically, he may be worried about how resources shifting around to fund the program will affect him e.g. fines for lack of coverage, what will happen to his current coverage/doctor, will taxes increase, will the treatments/medicines he needs be available etc.
Support universal health care by all accounts. They support it to the fullest extent of the law.
Conservatives believe that people should 'just work harder' and 'get a better job' that provides healthcare. They think they will pay an exorbitant amount in taxes to 'fund poor people's laziness'
Government is not in the healthcare business and healthcare should remain private
It is fair for everyone to have health care. People will not be worried about being ill and could be focused on work.
It is not true socialism. It's a state run activity to allow all citizens to take part in a free market.
Implementing universal health care would require a tax increase. Also, some individuals would receive lower quality care than they currently have access to.
That healthcare is a basic human right. It has worked for other countries and should be implemented in the US
The job of the government is to take care of its people. The government should therefor provide for everyone's healthcare.

The fact that the declaration of independence supports the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. Health care, in a sense, can be regarded as part and parcel of life and the pursuit of happiness. Thus, the founders were in support of UHC.

One argument is that if everyone is covered, costs will go down due to government's ability to negotiate with health care providers in ways that individual patients cannot and because costs from unnecessary treatments, especially at end of life, can be better controlled.
The cost to the government of providing healthcare to all citizens is too high.
The burden of higher taxes for some individuals. Not to mention oversight. It would surely impact insurance companies, causing high unemployment rates for that industry.

As a developed nation, we have a responsibility to ensure that no one suffers in the country due to lack of adequate healthcare. If the well being of citizens cant be ensured, what is the point of being developed? Many people cant afford these benefits and that is why we need universal health care.

Universal healthcare will raise taxes, which hurts the middle class. It also provides costly treatments for those who he believes do not contribute to society like he does, and he therefore does not feel obligated to pay for someone else.

There is a good amount of people working jobs in the insurance agency. These people would be part of the "Fat" trimmed by UHC savings. I just do not want them to get left behind because their industry will die. The reason people hate renewable energy is they got left behind when they stuff like coal mines closed.
Restriction of availability of medical treatment through quotas/queues. Restriction on choice of medical practitioner. Increase in people being denied treatment.
Health care is a basic human right and therefore it is our duty to protect our fellow citizens from disease and illness.
Why should one person be mandated to pay for another. The taxes required to implement UHC would be a burden on the taxpayer.

Healthcare is such a fundamental part of human well-being that it should be provided to all citizens. People who are ill or injured without access to healthcare are less able to function and fall further into poverty.
It’s too expensive/who will pay for it

the root definition of the word "free"; these programs will come with a cost for the taxpayer. Entire committees will need to be established and properly funded in order to allocate the proper treatments and faculties.

OK, my keyboard key tat comes between g and i is broken, so bear wit me. Peraps my opponent may tink tat universal ealt care would someow break te budget. Or maybe e is simply opposed to ealt care being given to tose e tinks do not deserve it. (i.e., "lazy poor," immigrants etc.)
Everyone should have access to health care in this country.  Being an economic leader, we can afford it.
Increase debt or taxes

One concern I've seen about universal healthcare is that the government would have more control over the populations healthcare. In the past, government programs or representatives have conducted experiments on subjects without their informed consent, or have subjected them to elective surgery (including sterilization) against their wishes, often without even informing the person.

Our tax dollars should not go towards funding the lazy, especially since the government is highly wasteful as it is. It would create a culture of dependency and no one would want to work, this is just an expansion of the welfare state.
UHC has been proven time and again to be cheaper for everyone in the long run.
it will raise the cost of healthcare in general. People also are immediately against something that means their taxes will go up.
Access to healthcare by all would increase the workload of an already strained healthcare system. It would also increase wait times for patients at doctors offices.
The cost in taxes that would be needed to implement UHC.  It would raise taxes that people pay.

The other user might be wondering who will pay for UHC given that there is no such thing as free money. The money needs to come from somewhere, usually it comes from raising taxes on Americans, she as himself. No one wants to pay higher taxes.

They do not want to have to 'pay for' insurance for other people. They do not think it's fair or necessary to have to pay into a system they don't (think they) need. They don't like 'big government' and don't want it 'in their business,' as it were, with regards to the type of health care coverage they have or what services are or are not covered. They think it's not a good use of taxes; they may possibly be against any taxes at all. They believe the free market can cure/solve all.
Everyone will have healthcare.  Everyone will have access to health care and a doctor.   People will be healthier.  People who are in bad health will not have to pay so much

UHC simply costs too much. The U.S.'s overall deficit is already staggering, and UHC would push us even farther into debt. Additionally, the government, and in extension my tax dollars, should not pay for another's health costs, especially since many poor health outcomes stem from poor personal life choices.
This individual is apprehensive of higher taxes. He also worries about perceived socialism
...that health care is a right and thus all persons must have equal access to it. This can generally be assumed to mean a single payer system is required.
It would cost too much of the federal budget to implement and would create rising wait times in emergency situations
One argument is that it will cost too much. Adopting universal healthcare would require increasing taxes and the people hit hardest would be lower and middle class people.
An unfair increase in taxes, that the rest of society should not have to pay for the health care of the uninsured or underinsured

Wait times and will be outrageous. Medical professionals won’t be paid enough. Incentive for innovation will go out the window. Medical care will be poor and rushed. Taxes will increase. Regulation will increase. The free market won’t be allowed to do what it needs to do.
Single payer systems have more control over one's choice of physician and access to specialists. Not different from a medical insurance, there's just no variance because everyone's on the same plan.

There should be a basic human right for healthcare for everyone. It isn't fair that the wealthy can afford better care than those who are less fortunate, and not everyone can work for an employer who offers a good health plan.
Universal health care is too expensive, and there’s no practical way for the government to pay for it.

It creates a lack of incentive among medical professionals to invest in research and innovation because prices are depressed through government funding. If we have universal health care, individuals don’t have the incentive to make good lifestyle choices to increase their health and rely less on healthcare. The healthcare insurance industry as we know it is a major source of jobs that would have to be eradicated or transitioned. Universal health care will limit choices for consumers.

The healthcare industry is flooded with fees and high expenses and they often occur in a short amount of time. This means while pretty much everyone can afford $10 a month, they often can't afford a huge bill at once. By having universal healthcare, it can help avoid situations where falling ill leads to crippling debt and or financial stress.

(I'm assuming this is for universal healthcare in the U.S.) /  / One argument against universal healthcare in the U.S. is that there isn't an agency that would run universal healthcare efficiently. As shown via the tax system and the veteran health administration scandal of 2014, the government isn't the best at administrating and managing some programs.

This will cause tax increases across the board, squeezing the lower middle-class and upper working class who already get hit with high taxes.  /  / By legalising Universal Health Care, many people who can afford to pay for healthcare themselves would likely drop expensive health insurance in favour of "free" treatment,  which would increase pressure on the "public" healthcare system.

Universal Healthcare is basic human right which a first world country ought to guarantee to its citizens. The countries which have implemented UHC have both lower costs and better outcomes than the U.S.
Ease of access for all people. Standardized care for all. Governing body for regulation
It would be expensive to implement.

The government shouldn't be involved so closely in the everyday lives of the citizens. Universal healthcare would remove autonomy of the individual to make important decisions regarding their own health care. Healthy individuals shouldn't have to subsidize unhealthy ones via taxes paid.

Healthcare is a privilege and a service and not a right.  If I choose not to carry coverage, I should be able to do so rather than be forced to pay out of pocket for a service that I may not use.  Universal Healthcare will cause inferior care ultimately because doctors won’t be paid well for their services.
Universal Healthcare could be expensive and that money will have to come from somewhere.

Illogical, but people don't want their money going towards helping others. They feel entitled to determine how their tax dollars are used and do not trust the government to make that decision. They also feel superior to people who aren't as fortunate as themselves, and they feel the less fortunate are also less deserving.

Providing healthcare from the government squashes competition, potentially meaning longer wait times, and higher costs. It may also mean that some people who do not pay taxes will receive healthcare at the expense of others.

The taxes in order to pay for universal healthcare would be too high for the common regular taxpayer. Another reason would be potentially over abundance of patients and not enough healthcare professionals to fill the need.
Universal Health care is a right. It is garunteed to the people by the government. The government should provide Universal Health Care to all citizens.
Lower quality of care. It will take a long time to receive needed health care, waiting lists. People will be denied care
Cost - Cut out profits & executive salaries. / I don't need, I'm prepared - You will or may. / Private sector job loss - Mostly executives & middle management.

Government interference will worsen healthcare. We should allow health insurance companies to compete with one another. This encourages companies improve their standards in order to attract more customers in order to get ahead their competitors, producing a win-win situation: the company thrives and the customer receives a good product.

It’s uncertain if it will work. It might also cost too much. There might also be the free market argument. It will also increase the amount of work the government needs to do which will go against the beliefs of those who want small government.
Universal healthcare will be too expensive to implement. An expensive new program will require raising taxes dramatically to fund it.
Universal healthcare will not work in the US because the US is different than other countries.  The culture and the people in the US are exceptional.

Healthcare is too expensive for everybody, especially disabled and lower-income. Many Americans will be put in a position where they cannot afford healthcare nor afford insurance for either themselves or their children. Which is extremely shitty.
It costs too much money and it's practically socialism. Everyone's taxes will increase and people will abuse the system. UHC can't work in America because ... blah blah American exceptionalism.
It might be difficult to fund at first and would increase the reach of the federal government.
It is costly to implement, and difficult to transition a healthcare system with 300 million patients from its current market-based state to a universal right.
It's too expensive/will raise taxes, the government cannot be trusted with people's health and lives, the free market yields better results
By providing care for everyone we would need to personally take money out if our pockets in the form of taxes. No one likes higher taxes.
One argue meant against universal health care is the fact that it requires increases in taxes. One person may end up paying more and having to subsidize others who are not paying taxes.

It would potentially take a long time for people to get care/treatment if everyone had access to it who wanted it. Government sponsored programs are notorious for having to go through a lot of hoops and I have heard from people in countries with UHC  that sometimes they have to wait a long time to be seen by the doctor.

I work and pay for my health insurance, if we have universal healthcare tons of people will be getting free healthcare while I pay for it.  / The government should spend its money on other things than this, see point 1 /

One argument against universal health care is that it would deincentivize people to take care of themselves and stay healthy, and that people should pay for the consequences of their own unhealthy habits. Also, some who are against it feel that the quality of care will decrease.
Insurance is intended to take money from people who don't need it and give it to the people that do. Most people pay for something they don't use.
It will raise taxes.
The entire insurance industry will be left jobless. So many lost jobs are bad for the economy. Why punish insurance workers just to push the liberal agenda?
We shouldn’t reward people who don’t work. We can’t give out something for free or it will destroy self initiative.
It will cost too much money.
Some people are against socialized healthcare because they feel that all forms of socialism are bad and that socializing American Health Care System would be a government overreach

I'm a selfish asshole and I want people to die. I think natural selection means that people who get sick and die will make Americans a stronger "race". I also think that preventing universal healthcare will somehow prevent immigrants stealing things from me.
That taxpayers shouldn't be held accountable for other people's health issues, especially those who don't take care of themselves. Health care is also considered a privilege and not a right.
Universal healthcare could be an expensive endeavor.  In theory it could have limitless cost and become unsustainable, or bring down the quality of healthcare.
People should be responsible for their own health care and should not have to pay for other's health. People should also not need to pay for health care when they are not needing it.
UHC could be considered socialism. This may cause people to not want to work.

If universal healthcare is implemented there will be longer waiting periods to see medical professionals than our current system. This could potentially worsen an individual’s health while they are awaiting care.
Possibility of higher taxes overall

Health insurance can be extremely expensive, and for many to such a degree that it is prohibitive. So, having the government pay for healthcare theoretically allows all citizens to have adaquete health care and unburdened poor individuals, and companies who provide health insurance to employees.

The cost of implementing and maintaining universal healthcare might be greater the cost of improving the current system. As long as the healthcare market is competitive, market forces will more efficiently distribute quality care.
One argument against universal health care us the cost. Like social security and other societal programs UHC often requires a significant portion of a governments budget to finance.
The burden on taxpayers is too high. It would force the many to take care of the few. I don’t want to pay for healthcare for someone who has made bad life decisions (smoking, drugs, overeating etc).
Its morally the right thing to do to support other people's healthcare in our country, and we should do so. Some anecdote about how AHA has helped them or someone they know.
Will lead to lower quality healthcare because everyone needs to be cared for and the system overrun.

Healthcare is a matter of individual responsibility. Individuals are in most cases responsible for their own well being due to their choices in diet and lifestyle. Society shouldn't have to foot the bill for someone who chooses to eat McDonalds every night.
It will make the health care insurance industry disappear and millions will lose thier jobs. I think they are 5% of work force so we need to make sure they don't all lose jobs
it will be too expensive to implement, and people will encourage people to mooch off of the system by not working.
Costs will go up for those already paying for healthcare. Making it more difficult for them to survive financially.

Universal healthcare will not run smoothly. Governmental organizations can often become bloated and corrupt. It's better to leave something as important as healthcare in the hands of private businesses, where the free market can balance itself out.

If universal health care is implemented, we will lose some of the financial incentive for people to pursue careers in medicine. Medical professionals are well-paid in part because the private insurance industry compensates them well. Should that incentive go down, then the best and brightest medical professionals may choose another profession that will allow them to make more money, thus decreasing the quality of care patients receive.

Because we live in such a large and diverse country, universal healthcare may not be an option for us because it is expensive. Universal healthcare would take more to implement and it is better to have it privatized with a free market.
